Posts.Content: Hetty172 wrote: She had a double mastectomy and immediate reconstruction on Thursday.  We think she might have gone a bit overboard with her morphine drip.  We (my sisters and I) asked that they cut it back a bit, and finally -- just today -- she's becoming lucid again.  The doctors consider her surgery a success, but I've never seen her this out of it before -- not even after her double lumpectomy and sentinel node section last month.  Anyway, they're considering sending her home tomorrow???  And I'm just so worried for her.  She's getting up frequently and can walk short distances today, but because she was out of it for last 3 days, I feel like she's behind in the recovery curve. Has anyone gone through something similar?  Is there anything that I can do to better advocate for her at the hospital?  Now that she's finally lucid again, she's saying that she wished she never got the reconstruction and is having a lot of regret.  I feel so bad for her ... she's a pretty positive and vibrant woman on a normal day ... this just isn't like her.  Any advice/support would be appreciated ... Posts.Content: May 22, 2008 04:25AM Hetty172 wrote: Thank you, ladies, for your input.  I really appreciate it!  It's been a couple of days since I posted and I'm happy to report that my mom is doing much, much better.  In the hospital, she went completely off the morphine and did much better with the Tylenol and the incision pain meds (there was a line that went directly into her abdomen incision site that administered a novicane-type medication?).  But once she got home on Monday, the change in her was dramatic.  She perked right up when she was able to get a shower and be in her own environment.  I'm so relieved.    wahine -- My sisters and I alternate spending time with her during the day and her boyfriend stays with her nights.  She's never alone, and we're all trained to handle her drains. AnneW -- she had a bilateral mastectomy and a TRAM flap last week.  Back in April she had a double lumpectomy and sentinel node dissection in the right side.
